content.text: State the SI base units of volume
base units of volume .........
Show that the SI base units of pressure are \(\text{kg} \text{m}^{-1} \text{s}^{-2}\)
The volume \(V\) of liquid that flows through a pipe in time \(t\) is given by the equation
where \(P\) is the pressure difference between the ends of the pipe of radius \(r\) and length \(l\). The constant \(C\) depends on the frictional effects of the liquid
Determine the base units of \(C\)
base units of \(C\) .........
Show that the downwards velocity of the ball when it hits the ground is \(19.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\)
Calculate, to three significant figures, the distance the ball falls to the ground
distance = .........m
Calculate the average force acting on the ball on impact with the ground
magnitude of force = .........N
direction of force .........
Use conservation of energy to determine the maximum height the ball reaches after it hits the ground
height = .........m
The ball makes contact with the ground for \(12.5 \text{ms}\) and rebounds with an upwards velocity of \(18.6 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The mass of the ball is \(46.5 \text{g}\)
State and explain whether the collision the ball makes with the ground is elastic or inelastic

A ball is thrown vertically down towards the ground with an initial velocity of \(4.23 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The ball falls for a time of \(1.51 \text{s}\) before hitting the ground. Air resistance is negligible
The mass is in equilibrium. Explain, by reference to the forces acting on the mass, what is meant by equilibrium
the mass is at maximum speed,
the elastic potential energy stored in the spring is a maximum,
the mass is in equilibrium
The mass is pulled down and then released at time \(t = 0.\) The mass oscillates up and down. The variation with \(t\) of the displacement of the mass \(d\) is shown in Fig. 3.2
Use Fig. 3.2 to state a time, one in each case, when
State and explain whether the spring obeys Hooke's law
Show that the force constant of the spring is \(26 \text{N} \text{m}^{-1}\)
A mass of \(0.40 \text{kg}\) is attached to the spring. Calculate the energy stored in the spring
energy = .........J
The arrangement shown in Fig. 3.3 is used to determine the length \(l\) of a spring when different masses \(M\) are attached to the spring
The variation with mass \(M\) of \(l\) is shown in Fig. 3.4
One end of a spring is fixed to a support. A mass is attached to the other end of the spring. The arrangement is shown in Fig. 3.1
Calculate the resistance of the heater
resistance = .........$\Omega$
The heater is made from a wire of cross-sectional area \(2.0 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}^2\) and resistivity \(1.1 \times 10^{- 6} \Omega \text{m}\)
Use your answer in (i) to calculate the length of the wire
length = .........m
The output of a heater is \(2.5 \text{kW}\) when connected to a \(220 \text{V}\) supply
Calculate the power output of the heater at this voltage, assuming there is no change in the resistance of the wire
State and explain quantitatively **one** way that the wire of the heater could be changed to give the same power as in (a)
The supply voltage is changed to 110V
State Kirchhoff's second law
Kirchhoff's second law is linked to the conservation of a certain quantity. State this quantity
Apply Kirchhoff's second law to the circuit CXYDC to determine the current \(I\)
Calculate the potential difference across the length of wire XJ
potential difference = .........V
Use your answer in (ii) to state the value of \(E\)
State why the value of the internal resistance of cell B is not required for the determination of \(E\)
The circuit shown in Fig. 5.1 is used to compare potential differences

The uniform resistance wire XY has length \(1.00m\) and resistance \(4.0\Omega\) . Cell A has e.m.f. \(2.0V\) and internal resistance \(0.50\Omega\) . The current through cell A is \(I\) . Cell B has e.m.f. \(E\) and internal resistance \(r\)
The current through cell B is made zero when the movable connection J is adjusted so that the length of XJ is \(0.90m\) . The variable resistor R has resistance \(2.5\Omega\)
Explain what is meant by coherence
Explain how an interference maximum is formed at \(\mathsf{P}_1\)
Explain how an interference minimum is formed at \(\mathsf{P}_2\)
Calculate the fringe separation
fringe separation = .........m
A laser is used to produce an interference pattern on a screen, as shown in Fig. 6.1

The laser emits light of wavelength \(630\mathrm{nm}\). The slit separation is \(0.450\mathrm{mm}\). The distance between the slits and the screen is \(1.50\mathrm{m}\). A maximum is formed at \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and a minimum is formed at \(\mathsf{P}_2\)
Interference fringes are observed only when the light from the slits is coherent
State the effects, if any, on the fringes when the amplitude of the waves incident on the double slits is increased
State the composition of the nucleus of X
The nuclei X are emitted as radiation. State two properties of this radiation
The spontaneous decay of polonium is shown by the nuclear equation
The mass of the polonium (Po) nucleus is greater than the combined mass of the nuclei of lead (Pb) and X. Use a conservation law to explain qualitatively how this decay is possible
